creditline: Gift of funds from Mary and Bob Mersky
description: portrait of a figure rendered in multicolored pigments, mostly red, with blue sections, outlined in thin, green lines, with light blue polka dots on shoulders and chest; image of figure dissolves into abstracted linear forms at the bottom; old photographs of families with young children, surround portrait; black background with blue text, some circled or outlined with red, green or blue lines; white section with "OCTOBER" in black pigment at TC; white rectangular section with Soviet symbol and text that reads "WHO OWNED HOW MUCH LAND?" inside, and outlined with red, jagged lines; black-and-white photograph in ULC
medium: Oil, oil pastel, and collage on canvas
signed: LRC, in purple pigment: K. Chiurai | 2019
text: The Zimbabwean artist Kudzanai Chiurai is known for his politically critical work, which landed him in exile in South Africa. His paintings are multi-layered collages that incorporate historical, artistic, and personal references—often difficult to fully grasp for an outsider. The sitter in this painting is unidentified. But the title (“October”), the depiction of a hammer and sickle, and the mention of land ownership all point to the October Revolution in Russia in 1917. Repossession of land was a big issue in the nascent Soviet state, as it was in post-independence Zimbabwe under the late President Mugabe.
title: October
